Award.AwardTitle: Supramolecular Complex Formation and Transport of Anions
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, George Gokel of the University of Missouri-St. Louis studies the chemical interactions that are involved in binding and transport of negatively charged species called anions, especially the complex and important anions DNA and RNA. A simple class of compounds called "tris-arenes", was found to bind to DNA and to mediate its transport through biological membranes into cells. The approach in this work is to address the fundamental chemical questions concerning the strength and selectivity of binding, the dynamics and energetics of binding, the structure(s) of the complexes formed, and the mechanisms of transport.

A particularly important impact of this work is the availability of these chemical tools to biological researchers involved in gene therapy research. The broader impacts of this project also involve training undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers, disseminating research results through publications and presentations at national conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The program of research is a continuing effort to understand weak force interactions and to use them in novel and practical applications. In some aspects of the effort, the chemical studies impinge biological systems. The intellectual focus of the work relates to understanding how cation and anion transporters insinuate themselves into membranes, affect (alter) ion transport and concentrations, and how they interact with molecules as well as with simpler salts. Understanding these mechanistic issues is a fundamental scientific question that broadly impacts chemistry, chemical engineering, biochemistry, and biology. All of these disciplines involve membranes, whether engineered or natural, and the concentrations of ions are critical to issues from the taste of drinking water to the vitality of cells.

 Thus, three key outcomes of the project can be identified. The first outcome is our ability to solubilize DNA and to simplify the “standard” transfection protocol. Transfection is a technique that permits external DNA to enter a cell. The ability to do this more efficiently or using a less complicated procedure is of potential benefit to chemists, biochemists, and biologists. It is well known that the solvent dimethylsulfoxide or DMSO (CH3-SO-CH3)is an excellent solvent for many molecules and salts. It is also known that DMSO can infiltrate cells (or even human skin) with deleterious effect at high concentrations. For this reason, chemists and biologists are cautious about its use over concern that cellular damage may occur. The solubilization of large and complex DNA fragments by using DMSO has been shown in the present work to present a simpler and safe alternative to the use of other solvent systems or lipids that require a more arduous procedure. This, in turn, simplifies the penetration of DNA into the desired cells in a transfection experiment.

 Further to the question of using weak force interactions to affect the properties of such molecules as DNA, we have developed a family of amino acid-based anion binders. The supported work has resulted in novel structures that bind anions in general and DNA phosphates in particular. The anionic phosphates are the “rails” in the “ladder” of DNA bases that comprise the genetic material. Complexation of the DNA phosphates alters the solubility of these large molecules making them amenable to characterization and use in a variety of experiments. During these studies, we found that the extensively studied lariat ethers and hydraphiles that we had developed as cation binders, can also complex DNA. This surprising observation remains under study in the current program. The structures involved are shown in Figure 1.

 The second important outcome is that a family of amino acid-based anion binders has proved also to show amphiphilic properties and to function as antibiotic synergists. An example of the type of compound is shown in the upper right of Figure 1. This is an exciting and somewhat perplexing finding. It is exciting because the amino acid-based amphiphiles have proved to be non-toxic to mammalian cells. Typically, in binding and transport studies, fluorescent chemicals are used as sensors. In the studies we have undertaken, bacterial death fostered by transported antibiotics was used as the metric for transport efficacy. Transport of antibiotics into and thus killing dangerous bacterial cells is of obvious practical value and potential importance. The results are perplexing, however, because the amino acid-based amphiphiles do not show structural properties that suggest an obvious mechanism for their activity. The biological aspects of these findings will not be pursued under the aegis of the NSF, but the mechanisms of binding, membrane penetration, and molecular transport are fundamental chemical questions that still require resolution.

 The third outcome of the research is that compounds previously thought of as “cation binders” show a significant influence on more complex systems than bacteria. We have found that the presence of low concentrations of these amphiphilic aminopolyethers also affect the development of the extensively studied plant Arabidopsis thaliana. In the presence of the various amphiphiles we have developed, these higher plants show significant changes in the development of their root structures. We have confirmed that this is not a toxic effect and it is not an effect equivalent to the action of a plant growth hormone. Thus, the mechanisms of how these various amphiphiles penetrate membranes and/or affect ion transport remain important open questions.
